Theoretical and Experimental Study of a Dismountable Traveling Wave Accelerating Structure for High Gradient Tests. (Structure Named MECCANO)
Etude théorique et expérimentale d'une structure accélératrice à ondes progressives démontable pour des tests à fort gradient (structure dite "MECCANO")

In order that future linear colliders can reach TeV energies within a reasonable length, one solution would be to use high gradient accelerating sections. With this in mind, the section MECCANO has been developed at the Laboratoire de l'Accelerateuir: Lineaire d'0rsay to study the physical and technical phenomena of high electric fields in traveling waves structures This thesis considers the behaviour of the electric field inside the section MECCANO from the theoretical point of view with nume1ical simulations and analytical representations, and from the experimental point of view ·with low and high power measurements: The results are analyzed and compared Classically, an infinite and uniform structure is described by series of RLC resonant circuits The basic RF properties of the fundamental mode are given from this pattern. Then, for a finite section, the matching of a ,forward or backward traveling wave of any phase advance per cell 1s also represented by means of RLC circuits. The variat10ns of the reflection and transmission properties of the structure with frequency and a new procedure to match couplers have been modeled and then experimentally verified The electromagnetic behavior of each different cavity and of the whole structure have been studied. The fundamental and fost high order modes have been simulated by 2D or 3D codes and measured at low power. The matching of the phase, the amplitude and the reflection level of the accelerator is described. This procedure is found to be extremely, delicate due to the abrupt changes in the geometry of the cavities. The structure has been tested with high power. Electric fields superior to 150MV/m have been reached. The physical and technical lessons learned regarding materials and surfaces subject to high gradients are presented
